questions.question_text:
A SaaS-based email service provider often receives reports from legitimate customers that their IP netblocks are on blacklists and they cannot send email. The
SaaS has confirmed that affected customers typically have IP addresses within broader network ranges and some abusive customers within the same IP ranges may have performed spam campaigns. Which of the following actions should the SaaS provider perform to minimize legitimate customer impact?

discussion.content: Answer is D as stated above.

In the past I have had to deal with this as an MSP representing the companies impacted. A was the correct approach. This question however is from the standpoint of the SaaS mail provider. Unusual that they would do anything to assist with this issue but I think the correct answer will be D.
D. Establish relationship with a blacklist operators so broad entries can be replaced with more granular entries and incorrect entries can be quickly pruned D

Maybe: B. Perform a takedown of any customer accounts that have entries on email blacklists because this is a strong indicator of hostile behavior
If I was the SaaS provider, and I have a customer that abusing the system, and thereby causing issues for my law customers, I would drop that customer in an instant. That said, just being on a blacklist does not mean you did anything wrong. As the question stated, many customers many customers are being wrongly blacklisted. The very best answer would be to find the problem customer, and drop that customer.

choices.D: Establish relationship with a blacklist operators so broad entries can be replaced with more granular entries and incorrect entries can be quickly pruned
choices.C: Work with the legal department and threaten legal action against the blacklist operator if the netblocks are not removed because this is affecting legitimate traffic
choices.B: Perform a takedown of any customer accounts that have entries on email blacklists because this is a strong indicator of hostile behavior
choices.A: Inform the customer that the service provider does not have any control over third-party blacklist entries. The customer should reach out to the blacklist operator directly

choices.C: The email was encrypted and an exception was put in place via the data classification application
choices.A: The employee manually changed the email client retention settings to prevent deletion of emails
choices.B: The file that contained the damaging information was mistagged and retained on the server for longer than it should have been
choices.D: The employee saved a file on the computer's hard drive that contained archives of emails, which were more than two years old

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D
personal storage table (PST) Is file format used to store messages and calendar events.
Users can create PSTs and control over these can be problematic. Chances are the email was recovered from the PST.

questions.question_text: An agency has implemented a data retention policy that requires tagging data according to type before storing it in the data repository. The policy requires all business emails be automatically deleted after two years. During an open records investigation, information was found on an employee's work computer concerning a conversation that occurred three years prior and proved damaging to the agency's reputation. Which of the following MOST likely caused the data leak?

discussion.content: If this is a zero-day exploit, why is compromising the patching system needed? Couldn't the patching system just as easily send out perfectly valid software that happens to have unknown exploits in it? (hence, zero day)
If the data is inherently malicious, wouldn't you want a digital signature? What good would a checksum do you?
C - Checksums

I would agree that B has to be the correct answer here. I do hesitate to say that though. But it is the quickest way to determine a compromise, as we should be able to identify that the digital signature doesn't match quickly, where as a sandbox on a zero day may take time to analyze.

comments.content: Your task is to identify whether or not your patch server is compromised, and you SUSPECT the behavior related to that compromise is a zero day attack and a back door. To confirm your suspicion that your patch server has been compromised, validate the digital signature against the patch vendor. If you are serving signatureless patches, your suspicion is confirmed. Sandbox to develop a remediation strategy, not to confirm your suspicion that you've been compromised.

discussion.content: E - Your task is to identify if the file contains a zero-day exploit and back door. Sandboxing allows you to trigger the file (and this any exploits) in a safe environment and identify any malicious behaviour.

comments.content:
B. Digital Signature.
Check that the signature matches the patch released by the manufacturer. If the patch you intercepted from your WSUS server doesn't match the signature of the same patch on update.microsoft.com, you can be certain your system is compromised. Sandboxing is a lot of time and energy (copy the file to a sandbox location, deploy it, and run forensics against the system) to validate a file which MUST have a digital signature you can just look at. While you may wish to sandbox in order to develop a remediation strategy for the exploit, but it's not the fastest or best way to be certain that your update server has been compromised (just check the file signatures!).

discussion.content: E. Sandboxing. A forensic analyst would want to run that .exe file in a safe environment, a sandbox, to confirm the patches are indeed compromised with a zero-day or backdoor. A checksum is used for checking data integrity.
E. Sandboxing

Digital signatures are a form of checksum, in that they provide data integrity, but they require asymmetric encryption to also provide authenticity. Digital signatures are away to attach an identity to the checksum.

comments.content: Agree. If the patch server was rogue then the checksum would match. So, you would want to verify that the patch was trusted by Digital Signature (and not just the integrity of the data, which was malicious to begin with)

discussion.content: A checksum is: a digit representing the sum of the correct digits in a piece of stored or transmitted digital data, against which later comparisons can be made to detect errors in the data.
C. Checksums

questions.question_text: A forensics analyst suspects that a breach has occurred. Security logs show the company's OS patch system may be compromised, and it is serving patches that contain a zero-day exploit and backdoor. The analyst extracts an executable file from a packet capture of communication between a client computer and the patch server. Which of the following should the analyst use to confirm this suspicion?

discussion.content:
A non-disclosure agreement, also known as a confidentiality agreement, confidential disclosure agreement, proprietary information agreement or secrecy agreement, is a legal contract between at least two parties that outlines confidential material, knowledge, or information that the parties wish to share with one another for certain purposes, but wish to restrict access to or by third parties

A master service agreement, or MSA, is a contract reached between parties, in which the parties agree to most of the terms that will govern future transactions or future agreements
C F is ansr
The most correct answers would be: NDA and SLA. But given what we've got. I would say: NDA and MSA are the best of the choices available.

questions.question_text: A company is acquiring incident response and forensic assistance from a managed security service provider in the event of a data breach. The company has selected a partner and must now provide required documents to be reviewed and evaluated. Which of the following documents would BEST protect the company and ensure timely assistance? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Provide digital certificates to all systems, and eliminate the user group or shared mailboxes
choices.C: Implement two-factor email authentication, and require users to hash all email messages upon receipt
choices.B: Federate with an existing PKI provider, and reject all non-signed emails
choices.A: Issue digital certificates to all users, including owners of group mailboxes, and require S/MIME with AES-256.

questions.question_text:
A security architect is implementing security measures in response to an external audit that found vulnerabilities in the corporate collaboration tool suite. The report identified the lack of any mechanism to provide confidentiality for electronic correspondence between users and between users and group mailboxes.
Which of the following controls would BEST mitigate the identified vulnerability?

discussion.content: Answer A seems to be correct. But are the other answers wrong?
A as stated above

A is correct. They want confidentiality and S/MIME is for public key encryption and signing of MIME data. I use it daily in my corporate Microsoft Outlook mailbox to send/receive/open encrypted emails.
